text: Bruce Feiler the author of the secrets
of happy families summer just around the
corner let's talk about family vacations
can you give me five secrets Freight
happy family vacation other than not
taking a family vacation tip number one
make a checklist for the trip okay I'm
following the lead of airplanes and
hospitals a creative action in this book
the first-ever family vacation checklist
things to do a week before a day before
and an hour before if you give your kids
the checklist it actually will empower
them to go around and check mom and dad
make sure everything is going to go so
tip number two I went to the folks at
the zynga they design online games i
said design me some better family
vacation games so the first game that
they designed is I'm thinking of a time
where so you're traveling in the car say
and someone says I'm thinking of a time
when everybody else has to ban together
ask yes or no questions it's a great
game to play if you're stuck in the car
okay that's good tip number three
missions let's just say you're in an
airport play a game called missions
where you send your kids out around two
I need three luggage tags for San
Francisco I need to know what time the
next plane to New York City leaves I
need to know tell me three things they
sell in that store and what's good our
girls are naturally shy so we would then
make them come back and make a
presentation
tip number four sometimes what you want
is a game that can last the three days
you're at Grandma's for the weekend or a
week if you're down at the beach so you
play a game called The Amazing Race
where you have a series of stunts okay
count the number of buses okay go over
there and climb up that rock and jump
off three times you do this and it can
last three or four days you gather point
don't be afraid to actually have your
kids fail at some of the missions that
will actually encourage them all the
research in the Gaming shows failing is
one of the big incentives to actually
work harder you want to create
opportunities for bonding and for
teamwork the last tip is do something at
the end to lock in the memories so we
started in our family creating a poem at
the end of every trip we do an acrostic
so wherever we have been San Francisco
New York Boston will write the letters
down and then write a series of our
favorite memories you can just make a
list of things that you learned or did
you can take pictures if you're really
much more organized than we are and
create a little scrapbook but the reason
is we now know from the research and if
you lock in positive memories you can
actually enhance your children's memory
of that positive experience so you've
had a great summer vacation you don't
want it to evaporate if you make a
little book you write a poem put it on
the fridge it will actually help people
to remember that when you're back in
school you're pushing them to get out
the door to their homework they'll
remember that positive bond and it will
make those difficult moments go get it
sweet all right thanks happy trails
right yes yeah have a great vacation
yeah
